docs.lead_paragraph: DUCKLER--Naomi Weinstein, died on July 17 at her home in the Catalina Foothills, in Tucson, AZ, surrounded by her four children and husband, Marvin Ira Duckler. She was to celebrate her 80th birthday, and 60th wedding anniversary this year. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Naomi held Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Nutrition and Food Science from Brooklyn College. Mother, nurturer, and beloved by her four children: Ariel Eva Duckler-Levy; Mordecai (Max) Sam Duckler; Ana Miryam Duckler Forest; Sara Rebecca Duckler. Proud grandmother of ten grandchildren, David, Lily, Gali, Nadav, Eva, Matan, Adam, Benjamin, Isabella, and Rachel. She is also survived by her two brothers, William Weinstein of Toronto, Canada, and the Hon. Judge Jack B. Weinstein, of the E.D.N.Y. Naomi was a mensch, with a beautiful character who always wanted everyone to be happy. A gentle and intelligent sense of humor, and a love and appreciation for all. She will be profoundly missed for her brilliant smile and laughter, sparkling blue eyes, her innocence and worldliness, her purity, truth, decency, honesty, faithfulness, her humor and generosity; a woman of honor and love. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your preferred charity.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCKLER, NAOMI WEINSTEIN

docs.lead_paragraph: Should states take children from their parents and place them in foster care in cases of “life-threatening childhood obesity”? It is not a new question (I wrote this magazine article about it several years ago), but it was given new amplification and caused a new uproar when advocated in a commentary in the most recent Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline.main: Removing  Obese Children From Their Parents

docs.abstract: How what you eat in utero can affect your child’s health for decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite fewer high-paying jobs, students continue to pour into law school. And the schools keep charging higher tuition and admitting more students.

headline.seo: Law School Economics - Job Market Weakens, Tuition Rises

docs.snippet: Despite fewer high-paying jobs, students continue to pour into law school. And the schools keep charging higher tuition and admitting more students.

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH apologies to show business, there's no business like the business of law school. The basic rules of a market economy -- even golden oldies, like a link between supply and demand -- just don't apply.
docs.abstract: Legal diplomas have such allure that law schools have been able to raise tuition four times faster than colleges; many law schools have added students to their incoming classes, which amounts to almost pure profit; law schools matriculated 49,700 students in 2010, up from 42,700 in 2001; drawing, photos (L)
docs.snippet: WITH apologies to show business, there's no business like the business of law school.     The basic rules of a market economy -- even golden oldies, like a link between supply and demand -- just don't apply.
